Our Multidisciplinary Team

Core Neurosurgical Team

  • Neurosurgeon: Dr Ales Aliashkevich provides surgical expertise and overall management of neurosurgical conditions
  • Neurosurgical Nurse Coordinator: Facilitates patient care, education, and communication between team members
  • Anaesthesiologists: Specialised in neuroanaesthesia for complex brain and spine procedures
  • Neuroradiologists: Provide expert interpretation of neuroimaging and interventional procedures

Extended Care Team

  • Neurologists: Collaborate on complex neurological conditions and diagnostic workups
  • Rehabilitation Specialists: Physiatrists, physiotherapists, and occupational therapists for pre and post-surgical rehabilitation
  • Pain Management Specialists: For complex pain conditions and perioperative pain management
  • Oncologists: For patients with brain or spinal tumors requiring adjuvant therapy
  • Endocrinologists: For pituitary disorders and metabolic optimisation before surgery
  • Psychiatrists/Psychologists: For psychological support and management of comorbid mental health conditions

The GP's Crucial Role

General practitioners are integral members of our multidisciplinary team, providing:

  • Comprehensive knowledge of the patient's medical history and comorbidities
  • Continuity of care before, during, and after neurosurgical intervention
  • Coordination of multiple specialist recommendations
  • Medication management and reconciliation
  • Psychosocial support for patients and families
  • Early identification of complications or concerns during recovery

Communication Pathways

We prioritize clear communication with referring GPs through:

  • Detailed consultation letters provided within 48 hours of patient assessment
  • Direct phone access to our neurosurgical team for urgent concerns
  • Regular case conferences for complex patients (in-person or via telehealth)
  • Secure electronic communication for ongoing updates and care coordination
  • GP hotline for rapid access to neurosurgical advice: (03) 9008 4200

Multidisciplinary Case Conferences:

For complex cases, we hold regular multidisciplinary team meetings. Referring GPs are welcome to participate in these discussions, either in person or via telehealth. Please contact our office if you would like to be involved in case discussions for your patients.

 {t.gpResources.careCoordination.preoperativeManagement.title}

{t.gpResources.careCoordination.preoperativeManagement.description}

Preoperative Optimisation

Medical Optimisation

GPs play a crucial role in optimising patients' medical status before neurosurgery:

  • Cardiovascular assessment: Optimise blood pressure control, manage arrhythmias, consider cardiology referral for high-risk patients
  • Diabetes management: Aim for HbA1c <8% when possible, establish clear perioperative diabetes management plan
  • Respiratory optimisation: Address COPD/asthma, encourage smoking cessation (ideally 6-8 weeks before surgery), consider pulmonary function tests for high-risk patients
  • Anticoagulation management: Follow our perioperative anticoagulation protocol (available on request) for patients on anticoagulants or antiplatelets
  • Nutrition and hydration: Address malnutrition, optimise protein intake, correct electrolyte abnormalities
  • Infection risk reduction: Treat any active infections, ensure appropriate vaccinations are up to date

Medication Management

Guidelines for common medications before neurosurgery:

  • Anticoagulants/Antiplatelets:
    • Warfarin: Usually stopped 5 days before surgery, bridging with LMWH if high thrombotic risk
    • DOACs: Typically stopped 48-72 hours before surgery depending on renal function
    • Aspirin: Usually stopped 7 days before intracranial surgery; may continue for some spine procedures
    • Clopidogrel: Usually stopped 7-10 days before surgery
  • Antihypertensives: Generally continue most antihypertensives; ACE inhibitors/ARBs may be held on the morning of surgery
  • Diabetic medications: Individualized management; typically oral hypoglycemics held on day of surgery, insulin doses adjusted
  • Steroids: Patients on chronic steroids require stress dosing perioperatively
  • Psychiatric medications: Most should be continued; MAOIs require special consideration
  • Herbal supplements: Stop most herbal supplements 2 weeks before surgery

Psychosocial Preparation

  • Anxiety management: Address surgical anxiety, consider short-term anxiolytics if needed
  • Expectations setting: Ensure patient has realistic understanding of recovery timeline and potential outcomes
  • Social support assessment: Identify support needs for post-discharge care
  • Advance care planning: Encourage discussion of healthcare preferences and documentation of advance directives

Preoperative Testing

Standard preoperative tests typically include:

  • Blood tests: CBC, electrolytes, renal function, coagulation studies
  • ECG: For patients over 45 years or with cardiovascular risk factors
  • Chest X-ray: For patients with pulmonary disease or symptoms
  • Additional tests based on individual risk factors and procedure complexity

GPs can facilitate these tests in the community setting when appropriate, with results forwarded to our office before the patient's preoperative assessment.

Preoperative Checklist for GPs:

We provide a comprehensive preoperative checklist for GPs to ensure all aspects of preparation are addressed. This can be downloaded from our website or requested from our office. For complex patients, we welcome direct discussion with our preoperative assessment team.

 {t.gpResources.careCoordination.postoperativeFollowUp.title}

{t.gpResources.careCoordination.postoperativeFollowUp.description}

Discharge Planning and Communication

Following neurosurgical procedures, we provide:

  • Comprehensive discharge summary sent to the GP within 24-48 hours of discharge
  • Detailed postoperative instructions for both patient and GP
  • Medication reconciliation with clear guidance on continuing, modifying, or discontinuing medications
  • Follow-up appointment schedule with our neurosurgical team
  • Recommended timeline for GP review (typically 7-10 days post-discharge)

Common Postoperative Concerns

Cranial Surgery Follow-Up

  • Wound care: Incisions typically have absorbable sutures with Steri-strips or staples (removed 10-14 days postoperatively)
  • Activity restrictions: Gradual return to activities over 4-6 weeks; no driving until cleared by neurosurgeon (typically 2-4 weeks)
  • Medication management: Particular attention to anticonvulsants, steroids (tapering schedule), and pain management
  • Neurological monitoring: Regular assessment of neurological function, headaches, vision changes
  • Red flags: Increasing headache, new neurological deficits, CSF leak, signs of infection, seizures

Spine Surgery Follow-Up

  • Wound care: Similar to cranial surgery; monitor for drainage or dehiscence
  • Activity restrictions: Procedure-specific limitations on lifting, bending, twisting; gradual increase in walking
  • Bracing: Some patients require cervical or lumbar bracing; ensure proper fit and compliance
  • Pain management: Expected pain patterns, appropriate analgesic use, weaning protocols
  • Rehabilitation: Timing of physiotherapy initiation, appropriate exercises
  • Red flags: New or worsening neurological deficits, severe pain unresponsive to medication, signs of infection, CSF leak

Rehabilitation Coordination

GPs play a vital role in coordinating rehabilitation services:

  • Outpatient physiotherapy: Referral timing and appropriate program selection
  • Occupational therapy: For assistance with activities of daily living and return to work planning
  • Neuropsychological assessment: When cognitive changes are present
  • Speech therapy: For patients with language or swallowing difficulties
  • Community support services: Coordination of home care needs

Our team can provide procedure-specific rehabilitation protocols and recommendations to guide these referrals.

When to Contact the Neurosurgical Team:

  • New or worsening neurological deficits
  • Suspected wound infection or CSF leak
  • Severe, uncontrolled pain
  • New seizure activity
  • Significant medication side effects

Our team is available 24/7 for urgent postoperative concerns. For non-urgent questions, please contact our nurse coordinator during business hours.

 {t.gpResources.careCoordination.sharedCareModels.title}

{t.gpResources.careCoordination.sharedCareModels.description}

Structured Shared Care Approaches

Chronic Spine Condition Management

For patients with chronic degenerative spine conditions:

  • Initial neurosurgical assessment with comprehensive management plan
  • GP-led ongoing management with agreed parameters for re-referral
  • Shared decision-making regarding timing of surgical intervention
  • Coordinated conservative care including medication management, targeted physiotherapy, and pain management strategies
  • Regular neurosurgical review (typically every 6-12 months) for patients with progressive conditions

Brain Tumor Surveillance

For patients with stable brain tumors requiring monitoring:

  • Neurosurgical establishment of monitoring protocol (imaging frequency and type)
  • GP coordination of surveillance imaging
  • Shared review of results with clear guidelines for when neurosurgical re-assessment is needed
  • GP management of associated symptoms with neurosurgical input as needed
  • Joint monitoring for quality of life impacts and functional changes

Post-Surgical Long-Term Follow-Up

Following successful neurosurgical intervention:

  • Transition to GP-led care after initial postoperative period
  • Structured monitoring protocol with clear guidance on what to monitor
  • Agreed indications for re-referral to neurosurgery
  • Annual neurosurgical review for complex cases or implanted hardware
  • Shared electronic health record access when available

Tools to Support Shared Care

  • Shared Care Plans: Documented plans outlining responsibilities, monitoring parameters, and communication pathways
  • GP Resource Portal: Access to condition-specific management guidelines, patient education materials, and referral criteria
  • Telehealth Case Conferences: Regular opportunities for GPs to discuss complex patients with our neurosurgical team
  • GP Education Sessions: Regular updates on neurosurgical management approaches and new technologies
  • Patient-Held Records: Encouraging patients to maintain their own health records to facilitate information sharing

Collaborative Research Opportunities

We welcome GP participation in neurosurgical research:

  • Clinical trials for new neurosurgical interventions
  • Quality improvement initiatives in perioperative care
  • Long-term outcome studies of neurosurgical procedures
  • Development and evaluation of shared care models

Interested GPs are encouraged to contact our research coordinator for current opportunities.

Developing a Shared Care Agreement:

For patients with complex neurosurgical conditions requiring ongoing management, we offer formalized shared care agreements. These documents outline the roles and responsibilities of the neurosurgical team, GP, and other involved specialists, ensuring coordinated care and clear communication pathways. Please contact our office to discuss establishing such an agreement for your patients.

{/* Main Content */}

What is Cervical Disc Replacement?

Cervical disc replacement (also known as cervical arthroplasty) is an advanced surgical procedure that involves removing a damaged disc in the neck and replacing it with an artificial disc device. Unlike traditional fusion surgery, which eliminates motion at the treated level, disc replacement aims to preserve normal neck movement while relieving pain and neurological symptoms.

Dr Ales Aliashkevich is a strong advocate for motion-preserving spinal surgery. He has been using cervical disc replacement in hundreds of patients with chronic neck pain, radiculopathy and myelopathy since 2006, achieving excellent results. Over the years, he has gained extensive experience in single and multilevel arthroplasty and hybrid procedures.

History of Cervical Disc Replacement

Surgery of the cervical discs began evolving in the 1950s. Dr. Robert Robinson, an orthopedic surgeon, and Dr. George Smith, a neurosurgeon, from John Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, United States published an article "Anterolateral cervical disc removal and interbody fusion for cervical disc syndrome" in 1955.

Cervical total disc replacement surgery began in Australia in the 1990s, but Medicare stopped funding it mainly because of poor results with the first-generation prostheses. Decades of biomechanical research, engineering, and meticulous clinical studies were required to achieve advances in medical device technology and to produce the current line of artificial intervertebral discs.

Understanding Cervical Disc Disease

Natural aging of the disc (degeneration) or trauma can affect its mobility and cause a reduction of its cushioning function. Structurally, it may manifest in a disc protrusion or formation of bone spurs (osteophytes) causing pressure on the neural structures and resulting in neck and arm/shoulder pain, numbness, or weakness.

Cervical arthroplasty is aimed at restoring the shock-absorbing function of the damaged or degenerated intervertebral disc with simultaneous decompression of the spinal cord and nerve roots. Similar to well-established hip and knee joint replacement procedures, the evolution of artificial disc prostheses has resulted in dramatic improvements in patients' quality of life and high levels of patient satisfaction.

The initial treatment of cervical disc disease involves rest, gentle physical therapy, painkillers or anti-inflammatory medications. Sometimes, spinal nerve root injections with local anesthetic or steroids can be applied. Surgical treatment is taken into consideration only as the very last resort to manage intractable pain or neurological deficit.

When is Cervical Disc Replacement Recommended?

Dr. Aliashkevich may recommend cervical disc replacement for patients with:

  • Cervical disc herniation causing arm pain, numbness, or weakness
  • Cervical degenerative disc disease
  • Cervical radiculopathy (pinched nerve)
  • Cervical myelopathy (spinal cord compression)
  • Failed conservative treatments such as physical therapy, medications, or injections

Benefits of Cervical Disc Replacement

Preserved Motion

Maintains natural neck movement, allowing you to look up, down, and side to side more naturally than with fusion.

Reduced Adjacent Segment Disease

By preserving motion, disc replacement reduces stress on adjacent discs, potentially preventing future problems at those levels.

Faster Recovery

Many patients experience quicker recovery compared to fusion surgery, with less postoperative pain and earlier return to activities.

No Bone Graft Needed

Unlike fusion, disc replacement doesn't require bone grafting, eliminating potential graft site pain and complications.

Cervical Disc Implants

Modern artificial cervical disc implants are available in variable shapes, sizes, heights and articulation types. Some of the commonly used implants include:

Bryan Disc (Medtronic)

A semi-constrained device made of titanium alloy plates and a polyurethane center surrounded by a saline-filled sheath. The plate surfaces are porous with an anterior stop to prevent posterior dislocation.

Discover Prosthesis (DePuy Synthes)

An unconstrained ball-and-socket device made up of two titanium plates with a stiff polyethylene center. The plates are coated with porous titanium and hydroxyapatite and have small teeth.

Mobi-C Disc (Zimmer Biomet)

Made from cobalt-chromium-molybdenum alloy coated with a titanium and hydroxyapatite spray. It has a polyethylene center which is supposed to move between two stops providing translational freedom.

CP-ESP Disc

A newer generation disc with a viscoelastic core that more closely mimics the natural properties of a human disc, allowing for shock absorption and natural movement.

The Procedure

Cervical disc replacement is typically performed under general anaesthesia and involves:

  1. A small incision in the front of the neck (anterior approach)
  2. Careful retraction of soft tissues to access the spine
  3. Removal of the damaged disc and any bone spurs
  4. Decompression of the spinal cord and nerve roots
  5. Precise placement of the artificial disc device
  6. Closure of the incision, often with dissolvable sutures

The procedure typically takes 1-2 hours, and most patients stay in the hospital for 1-2 days after surgery. The surgical approach can be performed from the left or right side, depending on the dominant symptoms. The incision is usually made slightly off midline after injection of local anesthetic.

Recovery and Rehabilitation

Recovery after cervical disc replacement varies from patient to patient, but generally includes:

  • Hospital stay of 1-2 days
  • Wearing a soft collar for comfort (if needed) for a short period
  • Gradual return to normal activities over 2-6 weeks
  • Physical therapy to strengthen neck muscles and improve range of motion
  • Follow-up appointments to monitor healing and progress

Most patients can return to light work within 1-2 weeks and more strenuous activities within 6-12 weeks, depending on their specific situation and Dr. Aliashkevich's recommendations.

For the first days at home, patients are recommended to avoid lifting weights over 2-3 kg and to engage in any strenuous or repetitive activities that may affect the neck. Most patients are capable of returning to their normal activities and light work within a few weeks of surgery.

Comparison with ACDF (Anterior Cervical Discectomy and Fusion)

Both artificial cervical disc replacement and anterior cervical discectomy and fusion (ACDF) offer very favorable clinical outcomes, reaching satisfaction rates higher than 80-90% in appropriately selected patients. However, there are important differences to consider:

Cervical Disc Replacement

  • Preserves motion at the treated level
  • Reduces stress on adjacent discs
  • May prevent adjacent segment disease
  • Faster recovery in many cases
  • No bone graft needed
  • Maintains more natural neck biomechanics

ACDF

  • Eliminates motion at the treated level
  • Well-established procedure with long-term data
  • May be more suitable for certain conditions
  • Ability to address multi-level pathology
  • Wider insurance coverage
  • May be preferred for patients with certain anatomical factors

As a general rule, Dr Aliashkevich would recommend considering cervical disc replacement as the preferred choice over fusion. Only if it is not feasible, e.g., in multi-level pathology, consideration may be given to a hybrid procedure where disc replacement in one level is combined with fusion in another.

Long-Term Outcomes and Research

Long-term studies have shown excellent outcomes for cervical disc replacement. Research indicates:

  • High patient satisfaction rates (over 90% in many studies)
  • Maintained motion at the operated level for 10+ years
  • Lower rates of adjacent segment disease compared to fusion
  • Reduced need for revision surgery
  • Excellent pain relief and functional improvement

A landmark study published in the Journal of Neurosurgery: Spine showed that at 7 years post-surgery, patients who received cervical disc replacement had significantly better outcomes than those who underwent fusion, with lower rates of secondary surgeries and better overall function.

Why Choose Dr Aliashkevich for Cervical Disc Replacement?

Dr Aliashkevich is highly experienced in cervical disc replacement surgery and offers:

  • Expertise in the latest artificial disc technologies
  • Minimally invasive surgical techniques
  • Personalized treatment plans tailored to each patient's needs
  • Comprehensive pre-operative assessment and planning
  • Dedicated post-operative care and rehabilitation support
  • Extensive experience with single and multi-level arthroplasty since 2006
  • Experience with hybrid procedures combining disc replacement and fusion when necessary
  • Commitment to staying current with the latest research and techniques
{/* Sidebar */}

Eligibility Criteria

In Australia, cervical disc replacement is approved for patients who:

  • Have not had prior spinal surgery at the same cervical level
  • Are skeletally mature
  • Have symptomatic degenerative disc disease with radiculopathy
  • Do not have vertebral osteoporosis
  • Have failed conservative therapy

Contraindications

Cervical disc replacement may not be suitable for patients with:

  • Severe facet joint arthritis
  • Significant cervical instability
  • Severe osteoporosis
  • Active infection
  • Certain types of deformity
  • Rheumatoid arthritis

Dr Aliashkevich will conduct a thorough evaluation to determine if you're a good candidate for this procedure.

Related Procedures

  • Anterior Cervical Discectomy and Fusion (ACDF)
  • Posterior Cervical Foraminotomy
  • Lumbar Disc Replacement
  • Image-Guided Surgery
  • Minimally Invasive Spine Surgery

Patient Resources

  • Spine Health App
  • Exercise Library
  • Cervical Spine Conditions
  • Frequently Asked Questions
  • Preparing for Your Appointment
{/* Call to Action */}

Ready to Discuss Your Treatment Options?

Contact us today to schedule a consultation with Dr Ales Aliashkevich to learn more about cervical disc replacement and whether it might be right for you.

{/* Main Content */}

What is Lumbar Disc Replacement?

Lumbar disc replacement (also known as lumbar arthroplasty) is an advanced surgical procedure that involves removing a damaged disc in the lower back and replacing it with an artificial disc device. Unlike traditional fusion surgery, which eliminates motion at the treated level, disc replacement aims to preserve normal spine movement while relieving pain and neurological symptoms.

Dr Ales Aliashkevich is a strong advocate for motion-preserving spinal surgery. He has been using lumbar disc replacement in patients with chronic back pain, radiculopathy, and degenerative disc disease since 2006, achieving excellent results. Over the years, he has gained extensive experience in single and multi-level arthroplasty and hybrid procedures.

History of Lumbar Disc Replacement

The concept of lumbar disc replacement began in the 1950s, but the first modern artificial disc, the Charité disc, was developed in the 1980s in Germany. The technology has evolved significantly since then, with newer generations of devices offering improved biomechanics and durability.

In Australia, lumbar total disc replacement surgery has been performed since the early 2000s. Decades of biomechanical research, engineering, and meticulous clinical studies were required to achieve advances in medical device technology and to produce the current line of artificial intervertebral discs.

Understanding Lumbar Disc Disease

Natural aging of the disc (degeneration) or trauma can affect its mobility and cause a reduction of its cushioning function. Structurally, it may manifest in a disc protrusion, herniation, or formation of bone spurs (osteophytes) causing pressure on the neural structures and resulting in back pain, leg pain, numbness, or weakness.

Lumbar arthroplasty is aimed at restoring the shock-absorbing function of the damaged or degenerated intervertebral disc with simultaneous decompression of the spinal cord and nerve roots. Similar to well-established hip and knee joint replacement procedures, the evolution of artificial disc prostheses has resulted in dramatic improvements in patients' quality of life and high levels of patient satisfaction.

The initial treatment of lumbar disc disease involves rest, gentle physical therapy, painkillers or anti-inflammatory medications. Sometimes, spinal nerve root injections with local anesthetic or steroids can be applied. Surgical treatment is taken into consideration only as the very last resort to manage intractable pain or neurological deficit.

When is Lumbar Disc Replacement Recommended?

Dr. Aliashkevich may recommend lumbar disc replacement for patients with:

  • Lumbar degenerative disc disease causing chronic low back pain
  • Disc herniation with persistent symptoms despite conservative treatment
  • Recurrent disc herniation
  • Failed conservative treatments such as physical therapy, medications, or injections
  • Relatively young and active patients who want to maintain mobility

Benefits of Lumbar Disc Replacement

Preserved Motion

Maintains natural spine movement, allowing you to bend and twist more naturally than with fusion.

Reduced Adjacent Segment Disease

By preserving motion, disc replacement reduces stress on adjacent discs, potentially preventing future problems at those levels.

Faster Recovery

Many patients experience quicker recovery compared to fusion surgery, with less postoperative pain and earlier return to activities.

No Bone Graft Needed

Unlike fusion, disc replacement doesn't require bone grafting, eliminating potential graft site pain and complications.

Lumbar Disc Implants

Modern artificial lumbar disc implants are available in various shapes, sizes, heights, and articulation types. Some of the commonly used implants include:

ProDisc-L

A ball-and-socket design with metal endplates and a polyethylene core. It allows for controlled motion in multiple directions and has been in clinical use for over 15 years.

activL Artificial Disc

Features a mobile core that allows for translation as well as rotation, more closely mimicking natural disc movement. It has variable heights to better match patient anatomy.

LP-ESP Disc

A newer generation disc with a viscoelastic core that more closely mimics the natural properties of a human disc, allowing for shock absorption and natural movement in all directions.

M6-L Artificial Disc

Features an artificial nucleus and annulus design that aims to replicate the natural disc's structure and function, allowing for compression and controlled motion.

The Procedure

Lumbar disc replacement is typically performed under general anaesthesia and involves:

  1. An incision in the abdomen (anterior approach)
  2. Careful retraction of abdominal contents to access the spine
  3. Removal of the damaged disc and any bone spurs
  4. Decompression of the spinal cord and nerve roots
  5. Precise placement of the artificial disc device
  6. Closure of the incision

The procedure typically takes 2-3 hours, and most patients stay in the hospital for 2-4 days after surgery. The surgical approach is usually performed with the assistance of a vascular surgeon to safely navigate around major blood vessels in the abdomen.

Recovery and Rehabilitation

Recovery after lumbar disc replacement varies from patient to patient, but generally includes:

  • Hospital stay of 2-4 days
  • Gradual return to normal activities over 4-6 weeks
  • Physical therapy to strengthen core and back muscles
  • Restrictions on heavy lifting and certain movements initially
  • Follow-up appointments to monitor healing and progress

Most patients can return to light work within 2-4 weeks and more strenuous activities within 8-12 weeks, depending on their specific situation and Dr. Aliashkevich's recommendations.

For the first few weeks at home, patients are recommended to avoid lifting weights over 5 kg and to engage in any strenuous or repetitive activities that may affect the lower back. Walking is encouraged as it promotes healing and helps prevent complications. A structured physical therapy program typically begins 4-6 weeks after surgery.

Comparison with Lumbar Fusion

Both artificial lumbar disc replacement and lumbar fusion offer favorable clinical outcomes for appropriately selected patients. However, there are important differences to consider:

Lumbar Disc Replacement

  • Preserves motion at the treated level
  • Reduces stress on adjacent discs
  • May prevent adjacent segment disease
  • Faster recovery in many cases
  • No bone graft needed
  • Maintains more natural spine biomechanics

Lumbar Fusion

  • Eliminates motion at the treated level
  • Well-established procedure with long-term data
  • May be more suitable for certain conditions
  • Ability to address multi-level pathology
  • Wider insurance coverage
  • May be preferred for patients with certain anatomical factors

As a general rule, Dr Aliashkevich would recommend considering lumbar disc replacement as the preferred choice over fusion when appropriate. Only if it is not feasible, e.g., in multi-level pathology or severe facet joint disease, consideration may be given to fusion or a hybrid procedure.

Long-Term Outcomes and Research

Long-term studies have shown excellent outcomes for lumbar disc replacement. Research indicates:

  • High patient satisfaction rates (over 85% in many studies)
  • Maintained motion at the operated level for 10+ years
  • Lower rates of adjacent segment disease compared to fusion
  • Reduced need for revision surgery
  • Excellent pain relief and functional improvement

Multiple randomized controlled trials have demonstrated that lumbar disc replacement is at least as effective as fusion for appropriately selected patients, with the added benefit of preserving motion. Studies with 5-10 year follow-up show continued good outcomes with modern disc designs.

Why Choose Dr Aliashkevich for Lumbar Disc Replacement?

Dr Aliashkevich is highly experienced in lumbar disc replacement surgery and offers:

  • Expertise in the latest artificial disc technologies
  • Minimally invasive surgical techniques
  • Personalized treatment plans tailored to each patient's needs
  • Comprehensive pre-operative assessment and planning
  • Dedicated post-operative care and rehabilitation support
  • Extensive experience with single and multi-level arthroplasty since 2006
  • Experience with hybrid procedures combining disc replacement and fusion when necessary
{/* Sidebar */}

Eligibility Criteria

In Australia, lumbar disc replacement is approved for patients who:

  • Have not had prior spinal surgery at the same lumbar level
  • Are skeletally mature (typically 18-60 years old)
  • Have symptomatic degenerative disc disease with back pain
  • Do not have vertebral osteoporosis
  • Have failed conservative therapy for at least 6 months

Contraindications

Lumbar disc replacement may not be suitable for patients with:

  • Severe facet joint arthritis
  • Significant lumbar instability
  • Severe osteoporosis
  • Active infection
  • Certain types of deformity (scoliosis, spondylolisthesis)
  • Obesity (BMI {'>'} 35)

Dr. Aliashkevich will conduct a thorough evaluation to determine if you're a good candidate for this procedure.

Related Procedures

  • Cervical Disc Replacement
  • Lumbar Fusion
  • Minimally Invasive Spine Surgery
  • Image-Guided Surgery
  • Robotic Spine Surgery

Patient Resources

  • Spine Health App
  • Exercise Library
  • Lumbar Spine Conditions
  • Frequently Asked Questions
  • Preparing for Your Appointment
{/* Call to Action */}

Ready to Discuss Your Treatment Options?

Contact us today to schedule a consultation with Dr. Ales Aliashkevich to learn more about lumbar disc replacement and whether it might be right for you.

{/* Assessment Overview */}

Comprehensive Spine Assessment

Our comprehensive assessment tools help identify the specific nature of your spine condition through detailed questionnaires, pain mapping, and functional tests. This information is used to create a personalized care plan tailored to your unique needs.

The assessment process includes:

  • Pain Assessment: Detailed evaluation of your pain patterns, intensity, and triggers
  • Functional Assessment: Analysis of how your condition affects daily activities and movement
  • Medical History Review: Comprehensive review of your medical background and previous treatments
  • Imaging Results: Option to upload and integrate your existing imaging studies
  • Personalized Recommendations: Evidence-based suggestions tailored to your specific condition
{/* Assessment Types */}

Our Assessment Tools

Pain Assessment Detailed evaluation of your pain patterns

Our pain assessment tools help identify the location, intensity, quality, and triggers of your pain. This information is crucial for accurate diagnosis and treatment planning.

Includes:

  • Visual pain mapping
  • Pain intensity scales
  • Pain quality descriptors
  • Trigger identification
  • Pain pattern analysis
 Functional Assessment Analysis of how your condition affects daily activities

Our functional assessment evaluates how your spine condition impacts your ability to perform daily activities, work tasks, and recreational activities.

Includes:

  • Activity limitation analysis
  • Range of motion assessment
  • Functional capacity evaluation
  • Work impact assessment
  • Quality of life measures
 Medical History Comprehensive review of your medical background

Our medical history assessment collects important information about your past and current health conditions, treatments, and medications that may be relevant to your spine condition.

Includes:

  • Previous spine conditions
  • Treatment history
  • Medication review
  • Relevant medical conditions
  • Family history
{/* Assessment Form */}

Start Your Assessment

Imaging Upload Share your existing imaging studies

Benefits of Our Assessment Tools

Personalized Care

Integrated Approach

{/* Main Content */}

What is Image-Guided Surgery?

Image-guided or stereotactic surgery describes a procedure where image-based navigation is used to achieve the safest and most efficient access to the point of interest. Its principle is very similar to a car or mobile Global Positioning System (GPS) navigation. This technology acts like a GPS system for the surgeon, allowing for more accurate targeting of pathology while minimizing damage to surrounding healthy tissue.

Advances in medical technology have allowed performing less invasive procedures and treating brain and spine lesions that were previously considered inoperable due to their size or critical location.

How Image-Guided Surgery Works

The image-guided surgery process typically involves:

  1. Pre-operative imaging (MRI, CT scans) to create detailed 3D models of the patient's anatomy
  2. Registration of the patient's actual anatomy to the 3D models in the operating room
  3. Real-time tracking of surgical instruments in relation to the patient's anatomy
  4. Continuous visualization of the surgical field on high-definition monitors
  5. Precise navigation to the target area with minimal disruption to surrounding structures

A set of specifically designed tracked surgical instruments is used together with cameras or electromagnetic fields and computer software to capture and relay the patient's precise 3D anatomy in real-time. Spacious visualization and image manipulation in the operating theatre are based on the same principles as in virtual or augmented reality.

Usually, high-resolution patient images are obtained before surgery with fiducials placed on the skin and uploaded into the workstation for trajectory planning. This plan creates a virtual patient-specific 3D model of the brain or spine outlining the area of interest and critical surrounding structures.

This individual model has to be registered to the actual patient position on the operating table using infrared cameras or electromagnetic fields. Special optical reflective markers on the surgical instruments can be tracked by the computer and position of the tool can be displayed on the screen or in the operating microscope.

Applications in Neurosurgery

Biopsies

Despite advances in modern imaging technology, the only way to establish the histopathological diagnosis is by removing a specimen and investigating it under the microscope. The image-guided or stereotactic technique allows reaching even deep-seated lesions with minimal risk and obtaining samples for histopathological, microbiological and molecular biological investigations. With accurate tissue diagnosis, appropriate treatment of the pathological condition can be provided.

Removal of Tumours and Other Pathological Lesions

Successful treatment of brain or spine tumours and other pathological conditions often requires the maximum extent of resection with minimal impact on healthy surrounding tissue. Sometimes, tumours don't have a well-defined border and application of the image-guided technology allows real-time assessment of the surgical cavity and removal of even deep-seated and difficult to access lesions.

Cerebrovascular Pathology

Vascular lesions such as cavernomas, arteriovenous malformations, and aneurysms can often be very small, positioned deeply in the brain. Accurate preoperative trajectory planning and utilisation of the neuronavigation allows a safe approach to the lesion without disrupting important surrounding neural pathways.

Epilepsy Surgery

Surgery of seizure disorders involves the removal of the epileptogenic focus or disruption of the epileptogenic activity in the proximity of the critical functional areas. It is often impossible to distinguish epileptogenic cortex from the normal brain tissue even under the surgical microscope. Thorough preoperative assessment is required for accurate localisation of the focus, and the image-guided technology allows positioning electrodes for monitoring of the brain activity precisely.

Benefits of Image-Guided Surgery

The use of navigated technology has multiple benefits for patients when compared to traditional open surgery:

  • Better quality of treatment, including improved accuracy and complete removal of lesions
  • Improved outcomes
  • Smaller craniotomy size for removal of brain tumours and other pathologies
  • Decreased incision size with better cosmetic results
  • Reduced risk of infection and wound healing problems
  • Reduced risk of medical complications, e.g. chest infections and deep venous thrombosis
  • Reduced radiation exposure to the patient and operating theatre staff
  • Increased safety and avoidance of critical structures during the approach
  • Shorter operation time
  • Diminished reliance on pain medications after surgery
  • Faster postoperative recovery
  • Earlier and more efficient physiotherapy and rehabilitation
  • Faster return to normal activities and work
  • Shorter hospital stay
  • Reduced overall cost of treatment

Advanced Imaging Technologies

Dr Aliashkevich utilizes several cutting-edge imaging technologies in his practice:

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)

Nowadays, MRI is the number one modality in neurosurgical and spinal imaging due to its superb image resolution and contrast. We use it in all patients with brain and spine problems with only rare exceptions when it is not possible due to old cardiac pacemakers, cochlear implants, stimulators or other medical conditions. High-quality MRI is available not only at a preoperative planning stage but can also be used intraoperatively, e.g. to estimate the extent of tumour resection.

Computed Tomography (CT)

CT is the preferred modality for visualisation of bone and is much more compact than MRI. It is also significantly faster and cheaper, which makes it ideally suited for spine image-guided surgery when accurate placement of vertebral screws is required. It can also be used for intracranial surgery, including lesion removal, biopsy and other stereotactic procedures. It can also be used in conjunction with other imaging modalities, e.g. SPECT or PET for better representation of metabolic changes and chronic inflammatory conditions.

Neuronavigation Systems

Advanced computer systems that integrate pre-operative imaging with real-time surgical navigation, providing continuous guidance throughout the procedure. These systems allow for precise tracking of surgical instruments in relation to the patient's anatomy.

Fluoroscopy and X-ray C-arms

Although standard x-rays in fluoroscopy provide only two-dimensional images, the technological evolution allowed implementation of rotational C-arms which provide high image quality, compatible with CT scanner. The images obtained before or during surgery are uploaded into the computer workstation and processed to plan the approach trajectory, position of the lesion, predict placement of the implants, and manipulate 3D views during surgery.

Why Choose Dr Aliashkevich for Image-Guided Surgery?

Dr Aliashkevich is highly experienced in image-guided neurosurgical procedures and offers:

  • Expertise in the latest navigation technologies and techniques
  • Specialised training in minimally invasive approaches
  • Personalized treatment plans tailored to each patient's unique anatomy and condition
  • Comprehensive pre-operative planning using advanced imaging
  • Commitment to achieving optimal surgical outcomes with minimal invasiveness
  • Experience with complex brain and spine pathologies requiring precise navigation
  • Access to state-of-the-art imaging and navigation equipment
  • Ongoing education and training in the latest image-guided techniques

Robotic Spine Surgery: The Evolution of Image-Guided Technology

Robotic technology is the logical step in the evolution of image-guided surgical systems, which contributes to the surgical toolset of minimally invasive approaches. Robotic spine surgery combines the precision of image-guided navigation with robotic assistance to further enhance surgical accuracy and patient outcomes.

The robotic system works in conjunction with image-guided navigation to provide:

  • Enhanced precision in screw placement
  • Reduced radiation exposure for both patient and surgical team
  • Improved surgical planning capabilities
  • Increased stability during the procedure
  • Potential for smaller incisions and less tissue disruption

Dr Aliashkevich utilizes robotic assistance for appropriate spine procedures, combining the benefits of image-guided navigation with robotic precision for optimal patient outcomes.

{/* Sidebar */}

Is Image-Guided Surgery Right for You?

Image-guided surgery may be particularly beneficial for patients with:

  • Deep-seated or complex brain tumours
  • Tumours near critical brain structures
  • Complex spinal conditions requiring instrumentation
  • Vascular abnormalities (cavernomas, AVMs, aneurysms)
  • Need for minimally invasive approaches
  • Previous failed surgeries requiring precise revision
  • Epilepsy requiring precise electrode placement

Dr Aliashkevich will evaluate your specific condition to determine if image-guided surgery is appropriate for your case.

Epilepsy Surgery

Image-guided technology is particularly valuable in epilepsy surgery, where:

  • Precise electrode placement is critical for monitoring brain activity
  • Epileptogenic focus may be difficult to distinguish from normal tissue
  • Preservation of eloquent brain areas is essential
  • Minimally invasive approaches reduce risk and recovery time

Thorough preoperative assessment combined with image-guided navigation allows for safe and effective treatment of seizure disorders.

  • Brain Tumour Surgery

This guide is designed to help identify neurosurgical emergencies requiring immediate attention. If you suspect a patient has a neurosurgical emergency, please contact our emergency line immediately or direct the patient to the nearest emergency department.

Recognizing neurosurgical emergencies in primary care settings is crucial for timely intervention and optimal patient outcomes. This resource outlines key red flags, assessment protocols, and immediate management steps for common neurosurgical emergencies.

Red Flags Assessment Management Contact Protocol Neurosurgical Red Flags

The following signs and symptoms should prompt immediate consideration of a neurosurgical emergency:

Spinal Emergencies

  • Cauda equina syndrome: Saddle anesthesia, urinary retention, fecal incontinence, bilateral leg weakness/numbness
  • Acute spinal cord compression: Rapidly progressive weakness, sensory level, urinary retention
  • Spinal epidural abscess: Fever, severe back pain, progressive neurological deficits
  • Spinal epidural hematoma: Sudden severe back pain with rapid onset of neurological deficits, especially in anticoagulated patients
  • Malignant spinal cord compression: Progressive weakness, sensory changes, and pain in patients with known malignancy

Cranial Emergencies

  • Acute hydrocephalus: Headache, vomiting, altered consciousness, gait disturbance
  • Intracranial hemorrhage: Sudden severe headache, altered consciousness, focal neurological deficits
  • Cerebral abscess: Headache, fever, focal neurological deficits, altered mental status
  • Acute cerebral edema: Headache, altered consciousness, focal deficits, often with known brain tumor or trauma
  • Pituitary apoplexy: Sudden severe headache, visual disturbances, ophthalmoplegia, altered consciousness

High-Risk Patient Groups

  • Anticoagulated patients: Higher risk of intracranial and spinal hemorrhage
  • Immunocompromised patients: Higher risk of CNS infections
  • Cancer patients: Risk of malignant cord compression and increased intracranial pressure
  • Post-neurosurgical patients: Risk of CSF leak, infection, hemorrhage
  • Patients with ventriculoperitoneal shunts: Risk of shunt malfunction
 Emergency Assessment Protocol

When a neurosurgical emergency is suspected, a focused assessment should be performed while arranging urgent referral:

Rapid Neurological Assessment

  • Level of consciousness: GCS or AVPU scale
  • Pupillary response: Size, symmetry, and reactivity
  • Motor function: Strength in all limbs, noting any asymmetry
  • Sensory function: Check for sensory level or saddle anesthesia
  • Reflexes: Deep tendon reflexes, Babinski sign
  • Cranial nerves: Focused examination of relevant cranial nerves
  • Vital signs: BP, HR, RR, temperature, oxygen saturation

Cauda Equina Syndrome Assessment

  • Saddle sensation: Test perineal and perianal sensation
  • Anal tone: Check for reduced anal sphincter tone
  • Bladder function: Ask about urinary retention or incontinence
  • Bowel function: Ask about fecal incontinence
  • Lower limb power: Assess bilateral lower limb strength
  • Straight leg raise: Often limited or painful

Note: Post-void residual bladder volume >100ml is highly suggestive of cauda equina syndrome in the appropriate clinical context

Raised Intracranial Pressure Assessment

  • Headache characteristics: Severity, onset, exacerbating factors
  • Vomiting: Particularly projectile vomiting without nausea
  • Visual changes: Blurred vision, diplopia, visual field defects
  • Pupillary changes: Sluggish or non-reactive pupils
  • Cushing's triad: Hypertension, bradycardia, irregular breathing (late sign)
  • Papilledema: If ophthalmoscope available (may be absent in acute presentations)
 Immediate Management Steps

While arranging urgent transfer to an emergency department, consider these immediate management steps:

General Measures

  • Airway, Breathing, Circulation: Ensure ABC stability
  • IV access: Establish reliable intravenous access
  • Monitoring: Continuous vital signs monitoring
  • Position: Head elevation 30° for suspected raised ICP
  • Documentation: Record detailed neurological findings as baseline

Condition-Specific Measures

  • Suspected raised ICP: Consider dexamethasone 8-16mg IV if brain tumor/edema suspected
  • Malignant spinal cord compression: Dexamethasone 16mg IV stat
  • Suspected CNS infection: Blood cultures before antibiotics if possible
  • Status epilepticus: Follow status epilepticus protocol
  • Anticoagulation-related hemorrhage: Consider reversal agents as per local protocol

Note: Always consult with the neurosurgical team before administering steroids or other medications when possible

Imaging Considerations

  • Suspected intracranial pathology: Urgent CT brain
  • Suspected cauda equina or spinal cord compression: Urgent MRI spine
  • If MRI contraindicated: CT myelogram may be considered
  • Suspected vascular pathology: CT angiogram or MR angiogram

Note: Do not delay transfer to obtain imaging if this will significantly delay neurosurgical assessment and treatment

 Emergency Contact Protocol

When a neurosurgical emergency is suspected, prompt communication with the neurosurgical team is essential:

Emergency Contact Numbers

  • Neurosurgical Emergency Line: (03) 9008 4200
  • After Hours Emergency: (03) 9008 4200 (Diverts to on-call neurosurgeon)
  • Emergency Department: Direct patient to nearest emergency department with neurosurgical capabilities

Information to Provide

  • Patient demographics: Name, age, location
  • Clinical presentation: Key symptoms and duration
  • Neurological findings: GCS, motor/sensory deficits, pupillary response
  • Relevant medical history: Previous neurosurgical conditions, anticoagulation
  • Imaging results: If available
  • Interventions already performed: Medications given, other treatments
  • Current vital signs: BP, HR, RR, temperature

Expected Response Times

  • Phone consultation: Immediate to 10 minutes
  • Emergency department assessment: Upon patient arrival
  • Neurosurgical team response: Dependent on clinical urgency and location

Note: For true neurosurgical emergencies, the on-call neurosurgeon is available 24/7 and can provide immediate telephone advice while the patient is being transferred

Emergency Case Examples

If you've been told that chronic back or neck pain is just a "normal part of ageing" or that surgery is your only real option—think again. While degenerative spinal and neurological conditions are common, suffering through them doesn't have to be inevitable.

Dr Aliashkevich can provide scientifically proven, expert-driven strategies to help you understand, manage, and prevent chronic spinal and neurological conditions—without unnecessary surgeries or medications. Backed by over 30 years of neurosurgical experience, his approach is rooted in evidence-based medicine, biomechanics, and neurophysiology to keep your spine strong, functional, and pain-free.

Why Your Spine and Brain Health Matter More Than You Think

Your spine isn't just a stack of vertebrae—it's an intricate biomechanical and neurological system that controls movement, stabilises posture, and protects your spinal cord. When compromised by conditions like degenerative disc disease (DDD), spinal stenosis, facet joint arthropathy, or spondylosis, even simple activities can become painful challenges.

Your brain and nervous system also play a vital role in pain perception, muscle function, and healing. Chronic spinal conditions are often mismanaged because treatments focus only on structural changes, ignoring the neurological, inflammatory, and lifestyle factors that contribute to ongoing pain.

Scientific research has shown that neuroplasticity, inflammation regulation, and movement therapy can profoundly impact spinal health. This means your daily habits—from how you sit to what you eat—can determine the future of your spine.

Classification of Spinal Degeneration: Understanding Severity

Spinal conditions progress through defined stages, influencing treatment decisions:

1

Mild Degeneration

Early wear and tear with minor disc dehydration, occasional stiffness, and transient pain. Lifestyle modifications and posture correction are key.

2

Moderate Degeneration

Disc height loss, facet joint stress, and mild spinal canal narrowing leading to chronic pain and stiffness. Physical therapy, anti-inflammatory strategies, and structured rehabilitation are essential.

3

Severe Degeneration

Marked disc collapse, osteophyte formation, and nerve compression causing persistent pain, radiculopathy, or weakness. Conservative management remains first-line, but surgical options may be considered.

4

Advanced & Refractory Pathology

Disc herniation with nerve root impingement, severe stenosis, or instability. In cases where all non-surgical methods fail, artificial disc replacement (ADR) or spinal fusion may be required for pain relief and function restoration.

What You'll Learn Here (That Your GP Didn't Have Time to Explain)

  • The Science of Spinal Degeneration: What really happens as your spine ages and how to slow the process.
  • Pain vs. Structural Damage: Why you might have pain without injury—and why that changes your treatment options.
  • Surgery, Injections, or Lifestyle?: The real evidence behind common treatments and what actually works.
  • The Brain-Spine Connection: How stress, inflammation, and sleep quality influence spinal pain.
  • Proven Strategies for Prevention & Recovery: The best ways to protect your spine at any age, based on research-backed methods.
  • Advanced Surgical Options: When artificial disc replacement or spinal fusion becomes necessary.

Who is This Website For?

🔹 People with Chronic Back or Neck Pain looking for long-term solutions beyond temporary relief.

🔹 Those Diagnosed with Degenerative Spinal Conditions who want science-backed management strategies.

🔹 Individuals Recovering from Spine or Neurological Injuries needing expert-led rehabilitation advice.

🔹 Health-Conscious Professionals who spend hours at a desk and want to prevent spinal degeneration.

🔹 Informed Patients who want research-based guidance instead of generic, one-size-fits-all advice.

Your Expert Guide: A Neurosurgeon Dedicated to Keeping You Off the Operating Table

This site is led by a renowned neurosurgeon with over three decades of expertise in spinal and neurological conditions. Unlike the mainstream approach that often prioritises surgery and medication, we focus on functional restoration, movement science, and lifestyle-driven recovery—because managing your spine should be about more than just treating symptoms.

Science tells us that strengthening the core, optimising posture, and reducing inflammation are key to managing spinal degeneration. But let's be honest—nobody wants to spend an hour a day doing rehab exercises they'll never stick to. That's why we provide real-world, sustainable solutions that integrate seamlessly into your lifestyle.

Start Your Journey to a Stronger, Pain-Free Spine Today

If you're ready to move better, feel stronger, and take control of your spinal health, you're in the right place. Our expert-driven content, backed by clinical research, will help you make informed decisions about your spine and neurological health.

{t.gpResources.referralProtocols.description}

Urgent Referrals Standard Guidelines Referral Process Triage Categories {t.gpResources.referralProtocols.urgentReferrals.title}

{t.gpResources.referralProtocols.urgentReferrals.description}

  • Cauda equina syndrome: Saddle anesthesia, bladder/bowel dysfunction, bilateral leg weakness
  • Acute or progressive myelopathy: Spinal cord compression with neurological deficits
  • Severe or progressive motor deficits: Significant weakness (MRC grade ≤3/5) or rapidly worsening weakness
  • Spinal or intracranial infections: Epidural abscess, subdural empyema, cerebral abscess
  • Malignant spinal cord compression: Known or suspected metastatic disease with cord compression
  • Intracranial mass with significant mass effect or hydrocephalus
  • Pituitary apoplexy: Sudden onset headache, visual disturbance, and hormonal dysfunction
  • Acute traumatic spinal instability with neurological compromise

For emergency conditions requiring same-day assessment:

Contact our office directly at (03) 9008 4200 and request to speak with the on-call neurosurgeon, or direct the patient to the nearest emergency department and we can provide telephone consultation to the ED team.

 {t.gpResources.referralProtocols.standardReferrals.title}

{t.gpResources.referralProtocols.standardReferrals.description}

  • Clinical history: Onset, duration, progression of symptoms, exacerbating/relieving factors
  • Neurological symptoms: Detailed description of pain, sensory changes, motor deficits, and their distribution
  • Neurological examination findings: Motor strength, sensory testing, reflexes, gait assessment
  • Previous treatments: Medications, physical therapy, injections, and their outcomes
  • Imaging results: Please include reports and, when possible, provide access to imaging studies (disc or electronic access)
  • Relevant medical history: Comorbidities, previous surgeries, medications, allergies
  • Psychosocial factors: Work status, disability claims, psychological factors affecting pain perception
  • Reason for referral: Specific questions or concerns you would like addressed

Preferred imaging for common conditions:

  • Degenerative spine conditions: MRI (within last 12 months if possible)
  • Suspected spinal instability: MRI plus flexion/extension X-rays
  • Brain tumors: MRI with contrast
  • Cerebrovascular conditions: MRI/MRA or CT/CTA as appropriate
 {t.gpResources.referralProtocols.referralProcess.title}

{t.gpResources.referralProtocols.referralProcess.description}

  1. Submit referral via one of the following methods:
    • Secure electronic referral: Via HealthLink (EDI: drales)
    • Fax: (03) 9008 4201
    • Email: referrals@mineuro.com.au (please ensure patient information is securely transmitted)
    • Mail: Suite 4, 619 Canterbury Road, Surrey Hills VIC 3127
  2. Referral triage by our neurosurgical team:
    • All referrals are reviewed within 24-48 hours
    • Urgent cases are identified and prioritized
    • Additional information may be requested if needed
  3. Appointment scheduling:
    • Our team will contact the patient directly to schedule an appointment
    • Appointment timing will be based on clinical urgency
    • Referring doctors will be notified of the appointment date
  4. Consultation and follow-up:
    • Following consultation, a detailed letter will be sent to the referring doctor
    • Ongoing communication will be maintained throughout the patient's treatment

For urgent referrals or clinical advice:

GPs are welcome to call our office directly at (03) 9008 4200 to discuss urgent cases with our neurosurgical team.

 {t.gpResources.referralProtocols.triageCategories.title}

{t.gpResources.referralProtocols.triageCategories.description}

Emergency (Same Day)

  • Cauda equina syndrome
  • Acute spinal cord compression with rapidly progressing deficits
  • Intracranial hemorrhage requiring surgical intervention
  • Acute hydrocephalus
  • Spinal or intracranial infections with neurological deterioration

Direct to emergency department with neurosurgical notification

Urgent (1-2 weeks)

  • Progressive myelopathy
  • Significant or progressive motor deficits
  • Brain tumors with mass effect but without acute deterioration
  • Malignant spinal cord compression without acute deficits
  • Pituitary tumors with visual field defects

Semi-Urgent (2-4 weeks)

  • Stable myelopathy without progression
  • Radiculopathy with mild motor deficit
  • Stable brain tumors without significant mass effect
  • Trigeminal neuralgia refractory to medical management
  • Spinal instability without neurological deficit

Routine (4-6 weeks)

  • Chronic radiculopathy without motor deficit
  • Degenerative spine disease with manageable symptoms
  • Stable, small intracranial lesions requiring monitoring
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome and other peripheral nerve entrapments
  • Second opinions for non-urgent conditions

{/* Hero Section */}

Privacy Policy

How we collect, use, and protect your personal information

{/* Content */}

Dr. Ales Aliashkevich and miNEURO Brain and Spine Surgery ("we", "us", "our") are committed to protecting your privacy and ensuring the security of your personal information. This Privacy Policy explains how we collect, use, disclose, and safeguard your information in accordance with the Australian Privacy Act 1988 (Cth) and the Australian Privacy Principles (APPs).

About This Policy

This Privacy Policy applies to all personal information collected by miNEURO Brain and Spine Surgery, whether through our website, in person at our clinics, or through other means of communication. By providing your personal information to us, you consent to the collection, use, storage, and disclosure of that information as described in this Privacy Policy.

Information We Collect

We collect personal information that is reasonably necessary for our functions and activities as a healthcare provider. This information may be collected directly from you or, in some cases, from third parties such as:

  • Your general practitioner or other healthcare providers
  • Medicare or your private health insurer
  • Family members or carers (where authorized)

We collect personal information when you:

  • Schedule or attend an appointment
  • Register on our website or patient portal
  • Complete forms (online or in person)
  • Contact us via email, phone, or other communication channels
  • Provide medical information for treatment purposes
  • Participate in surveys or research (with your consent)

The personal information we may collect includes:

  • Name, address, email address, and phone number
  • Date of birth and gender
  • Medicare number, private health insurance details, and Department of Veterans' Affairs details
  • Medical history, current medications, allergies, and treatment information
  • Referral information from other healthcare providers
  • Diagnostic imaging and test results
  • Payment information

Sensitive Information

As a healthcare provider, we collect sensitive information, including health information, which is a special category of personal information under the Privacy Act. We will only collect sensitive information:

  • With your consent (which may be express or implied in the healthcare context)
  • When it is necessary for our functions and activities
  • When required or authorized by law

Collection from Third Parties

Where reasonable and practicable, we will collect personal information directly from you. However, in some circumstances, we may collect information from third parties, such as other healthcare providers. When we do so, we will take reasonable steps to inform you about the collection.

Purpose of Collection

We collect, hold, use, and disclose your personal information for the following primary purposes:

  • Providing medical services and treatment
  • Managing your healthcare, including diagnosis, treatment, and ongoing care
  • Communicating with you about appointments, follow-ups, and care instructions
  • Maintaining accurate and up-to-date medical records
  • Processing payments and billing
  • Complying with legal and regulatory requirements
  • Conducting quality assurance and improvement activities
  • Training staff and healthcare professionals
  • Managing our practice efficiently

We may also use your information for secondary purposes such as:

  • Research and statistical analysis (in a de-identified form)
  • Evaluating and improving our services
  • Responding to your feedback or complaints
  • Sending you appointment reminders or health information

Disclosure of Your Information

We may disclose your personal information to:

  • Healthcare professionals involved in your care
  • Hospitals and other healthcare facilities where you receive treatment
  • Medicare, private health insurers, and other payment providers
  • Government agencies when required by law (e.g., mandatory reporting obligations)
  • Service providers who assist us in operating our practice (e.g., billing services, IT support)
  • Your authorized representatives (e.g., family members, carers)
  • Our professional advisers (e.g., lawyers, accountants)
  • Entities involved in the sale or transfer of our business (if applicable)

We will not disclose your personal information to overseas recipients without your consent, unless required by law.

We will not sell, trade, or otherwise transfer your personal information to third parties for marketing purposes.

Security of Your Information

We take reasonable steps to protect your personal information from misuse, interference, loss, unauthorized access, modification, or disclosure. These measures include:

  • Secure electronic medical record systems with encryption
  • Physical security measures for paper records
  • Staff training on privacy and confidentiality obligations
  • Access controls and authentication procedures
  • Regular security assessments and updates
  • Secure disposal of records when no longer needed
  • Data breach response procedures

While we implement these safeguards, no data transmission over the internet or electronic storage system can be guaranteed to be 100% secure. If a data breach occurs that is likely to result in serious harm, we will notify affected individuals and the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) as required by the Notifiable Data Breaches scheme.

Data Retention

We retain your personal information for as long as necessary to fulfill the purposes for which it was collected, or as required by law. For medical records, we follow the retention periods specified by relevant health records legislation in Victoria and other applicable laws.

Your Rights and Choices

Under the Australian Privacy Principles, you have the right to:

  • Access your personal information held by us
  • Request correction of inaccurate, incomplete, or out-of-date information
  • Request not to receive marketing communications
  • Make a complaint about a breach of privacy
  • Request information about our privacy practices

Accessing and Correcting Your Information

You can request access to your personal information by contacting our Privacy Officer. We will respond to your request within a reasonable timeframe (usually within 30 days). We may charge a reasonable fee for providing access to cover our costs.

If you believe that any information we hold about you is inaccurate, incomplete, or out-of-date, please contact us, and we will take reasonable steps to correct it.

In some circumstances, we may refuse access or correction as permitted by law. If this occurs, we will provide you with reasons for the refusal and information about how you can complain about the refusal.

Cookies and Tracking Technologies

Our website may use cookies and similar tracking technologies to enhance your experience and collect information about how you use our website. This information may include:

  • Your IP address and browser type
  • Pages you visit and features you use
  • Date and time of your visit
  • Information about your device

You can control cookies through your browser settings. Disabling cookies may affect your experience on our website.

Third-Party Links

Our website may contain links to third-party websites. We are not responsible for the privacy practices or content of these websites. We encourage you to review the privacy policies of any third-party sites you visit.

Changes to This Privacy Policy

We may update our Privacy Policy from time to time to reflect changes in our practices or legal requirements. Any changes will be posted on this page with an updated revision date. Significant changes will be notified to you through our website or by other means. We encourage you to review this Privacy Policy periodically.

Making a Complaint

If you believe that we have breached the Australian Privacy Principles or mishandled your personal information, you can make a complaint to our Privacy Officer. We will:

  • Acknowledge receipt of your complaint within 7 days
  • Investigate the complaint and provide a response within 30 days
  • Take appropriate steps to address the complaint

If you are not satisfied with our response, you can complain to the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) at:

Office of the Australian Information Commissioner
GPO Box 5218
Sydney NSW 2001
Phone: 1300 363 992
Email: enquiries@oaic.gov.au
Website: www.oaic.gov.au

Contact Us

If you have any questions or concerns about our Privacy Policy or the handling of your personal information, please contact our Privacy Officer at:

Privacy Officer
miNEURO Brain and Spine Surgery
Suite 4, 619 Canterbury Road
Surrey Hills VIC 3127
Phone: (03) 90084200
Email: privacy@mineuro.com.au

Last updated: June 2023
